Award.AwardTitle: Nonparametric Bayesian Methods for Joint Analysis of Recurrent Events and Survival Time
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will develop flexible statistical models for joint analysis of recurrent events and survival time. In long-term, follow-up studies, subjects may experience a recurrent event at multiple times, where the observation of subject-specific recurrent events is terminated by end of the study, or a terminal event such as death. Scientifically relevant problems involving such data structures are prevalent in the biomedical sciences, as well as in econometrics and engineering. A critical issue in analyzing such data is that the history of the recurrent events and the risk of terminal event are interrelated. It is thus important to jointly model the underlying stochastic mechanisms, typically, in the presence of predictor variables that are expected to affect the occurrence of recurrent events and the survival time. A key objective of this project is to expand the inferential and predictive scope of existing techniques for joint analysis of recurrent events and survival time by developing novel statistical models that relax restrictive assumptions of state-of-the-art methods. To facilitate use of the methods by researchers and practitioners, publicly available software will be developed for implementing several of the statistical models. The project will create educational and research training opportunities for graduate students and seek to foster the participation of women and underrepresented groups in the research.


This research project will develop general Bayesian modeling approaches for joint analysis of recurrent events and survival time. The modeling framework builds from Bayesian nonparametric mixtures of Erlang distributions for the survival responses, with covariate effects accommodated more flexibly than proportional hazard regression models. Different classes of joint models will be formulated by combining the nonparametric survival regression modeling methods with parametric models for the covariate-dependent recurrent event point process intensities. The joint models will capture general dependence between the recurrent event and survival processes, while allowing for heterogeneity between subjects. The primary objective is to develop a comprehensive joint modeling framework that significantly improves on model fit and predictive performance relative to the state-of-the-art shared frailty modeling methods. In the context of regression modeling for survival responses, the project will also expand the methodology in the burgeoning field of Bayesian nonparametrics. The research project has a substantial analytic component with regards to study of theoretical properties for the various models, as well as a significant computational component with regards to achieving computationally tractable model fitting. The practical utility of the new methods will be investigated with simulation studies and through applications involving analysis of data from cancer patients.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed flexible statistical modeling and inference methods for the joint analysis of recurrent events and survival time. The relevant data structures record repeated occurrences of the event of interest at random times, with termination by a terminal event, such as the end of the study or death. This type of data is commonly found in medical research, as well as in economics and engineering. For such data-generating processes, the occurrence of recurrent events and of the terminal event are related to each other. Therefore, it is crucial to jointly model both the recurrent and terminal events to gain accurate insights into the underlying data generation process.

As the first step towards building a joint model, the PIs focused on developing nonparametric Bayesian (NPB) methods for survival regression. Bayesian nonparametrics is a burgeoning research area which has attracted many researchers in statistics and machine learning, with NPB methods successfully applied in several scientific fields. This research component explored NPB modeling for survival responses based on mixtures of Erlang densities, including the extension to incorporate categorical covariates, as well as an alternative approach built from dependent nonparametric mixtures of log-logistic distributions. The latter approach offers advantages by providing greater flexibility in incorporating both categorical and continuous covariates, while maintaining an efficient computational method for inference and prediction. The culmination of the project involved development of a joint model for the processes of recurrent events and survival times, leveraging the BNP log-logistic mixture model explored at the earlier stages of the research. For all project components, theoretical properties of the statistical models have been thoroughly examined. Moreover, the methodology developed in this project has been empirically studied using several simulation experiments, and analysis of data on recurrent (pericardial or pleural) effusion events for esophageal caner patients receiving two different treatments.  

The research findings from this project are of interest to researchers and practitioners that use advanced statistical tools to analyze complex data that arise in health, economics, and other areas. The project involved dissemination efforts in several directions, including research papers, research presentations at conferences (Joint Statistical Meetings in 2021 and 2024), and short courses and tutorials on survival analysis and Bayesian nonparametrics (Department of Mathematical Sciences at KAIST in Daejeon, South Korea, June 2021; virtual 2021 World Meeting of the International Society for Bayesian Analysis, June 2021; and, Bayesian Nonparametrics Networking Workshop, Monash University, Melbourne, Australia, December 2023). Moreover, some of the project methods have been incorporated into courses offered by the Statistics Department at UCSC, including courses on ``Intermediate Bayesian Inference’’, ``Bayesian Nonparametric Methods’’, and ``Bayesian Survival Analysis and Clinical Trial Design’’.

Finally, the project had an important educational and training component. Yunzhe Li, a Ph.D. student co-supervised by the PIs, graduated from UCSC in Summer 2024 with the Ph.D. degree in Statistical Science. His dissertation, "Flexible Bayesian Nonparametric Modeling for Time-to-Event Data”, was based on some of the research corresponding to this project.
